abstract_summ: By specimen type and home-based collection method, clinician-supervised self-collected oral fluid swab specimens detected 26 (90%) of 29 infected individuals, clinician-supervised self-collected nasal swab specimens detected 23 (85%) of 27, clinician-collected posterior nasopharyngeal swab specimens detected 23 (79%) of 29, and unmonitored self-collected oral fluid swab specimens detected 19 (66%) of 29.When we compared SARS-CoV-2 detection from patient-matched nasopharyngeal and saliva samples, we found that saliva yielded greater detection sensitivity and consistency throughout the course of infection.Due to the easy collection of posterior oropharyngeal saliva, the use of saliva as an alternative specimen type for SARS-CoV-2 detection is recommended.In conclusion, posterior oropharyngeal saliva and NPS were found to have similar detection rates in the point-of-care test for SARS-CoV-2 detection.Taken together, our findings demonstrate that saliva is a viable and more sensitive alternative to nasopharyngeal swabs and could enable at-home self-administered sample collection for accurate large-scale SARS-CoV-2 testing.
title_summ: SARS-CoV-2 detection in setting of viral swab scarcity: are MRSA swabs and viral swabs equivalent?Microscopic Review of Nasopharyngeal Swabs as a Means of Benchside Quality AssuranceSelf-Collected Oral Fluid and Nasal Swabs Demonstrate Comparable Sensitivity to Clinician Collected Nasopharyngeal Swabs for Covid-19 DetectionEvaluation of specimen types and saliva stabilization solutions for SARS-CoV-2 testingEvaluation of symptomatic patient saliva as a sample type for the Abbott ID NOW COVID-19 assaySaliva is more sensitive for SARS-CoV-2 detection in COVID-19 patients than nasopharyngeal swabsSaliva is less sensitive than nasopharyngeal swabs for COVID-19 detection in the community settingSaliva as a non-invasive sample for the detection of SARS-CoV-2: a systematic reviewNasal-Swab Testing Misses Patients with Low SARS-CoV-2 Viral LoadsPosterior oropharyngeal saliva for the detection of SARS-CoV-2Nasopharyngeal and Oropharyngeal Swabs, And/Or Serology for SARS COVID-19: What Are We Looking For?Nasopharyngeal Swabs Are More Sensitive Than Oropharyngeal Swabs for COVID-19 Diagnosis and Monitoring the SARS-CoV-2 LoadSaliva is a reliable tool to detect SARS-CoV-2Combined oropharyngeal/nasal swab is equivalent to nasopharyngeal sampling for SARS-CoV-2 diagnostic PCRSaliva offers a sensitive, specific and non-invasive alternative to upper respiratory swabs for SARS-CoV-2 diagnosis.Deep throat saliva as an alternative diagnostic specimen type for the detection of SARS-CoV-2.Evaluating the use of posterior oropharyngeal saliva in a point-of-care assay for the detection of SARS-CoV-2.Oropharyngeal Secretion as Alternative for SARS-CoV-2 Detection.Saliva as a Potential Diagnostic Specimen for COVID-19 Testing.
title_abstract_phrases: When we compared SARS-CoV-2 detection from patient-matched nasopharyngeal and saliva samples, we found that saliva yielded greater detection sensitivity and consistency throughout the course of infection.Due to the easy collection of posterior oropharyngeal saliva, the use of saliva as an alternative specimen type for SARS-CoV-2 detection is recommended.In conclusion, posterior oropharyngeal saliva and NPS were found to have similar detection rates in the point-of-care test for SARS-CoV-2 detection.Evaluating the use of posterior oropharyngeal saliva in a point-of-care assay for the detection of SARS-CoV-2.During the Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic, logistic problems associated with specimen collection limited the SARS-CoV-2 testing especially in the community.Saliva is a easily self-collected, highly sensitive specimen for the detection of SARS-CoV-2.SARS-CoV-2 detection in setting of viral swab scarcity: are MRSA swabs and viral swabs equivalent?Abstract: Background: The global pandemic of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-Related Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV2) has resulted in unprecedented challenges for healthcare systems.
